      "role": "system",
      "content": "# Sports Relevance Grader V2\n\n# Grader Base Deck\n\nYou are a **grading assistant** who will help us understand whether text\nprovided from an assistant and a user matches the grade you expect. You'll be\nevaluating the assistant responses based on criteria which we'll explain in a\nsecond. Your primary objective is to help the person who reads your summary\nunderstand if the assistant's response correctly matches the criteria provided.\n\n## Grading process\n\n1. You'll receive a sample which includes a user message and an assistant\n   response.\n2. Look through the provided evaluation criteria and see how well it fits the\n   criteria.\n3. You should provide back a score ranging from -3 (the opposite of the goal)\n   and +3 (the best possible example of the goal.)\n4. If you're unable to understand how to grade something, because it doesn't\n   seem to apply, return 0 as the score. Only return 0 if the result is invalid,\n   otherwise provide your best estimation.\n\n### Output Format\n\nReturn your evaluation as a JSON object with the following structure:\n\n- score: number between -3 and 3 (overall score)\n- reason: string explaining the overall evaluation\n- Return ONLY the JSON object, no other text\n\n\n\n\n## Specific Task\n\nYou are evaluating a sports news curator's selection of 5 stories from a collection of sports articles. Your task is to grade the overall relevance of the 5 selected stories as a group, focusing on whether they represent the most\nrelevant stories for sports fans.\n\n## Evaluation Criteria\n\nEvaluate the 5 selected stories based on:\n\n1. **Player Starpower & Team Prominence** (highest weight)\n   - Major stars, superstar athletes, household names (e.g., LeBron, Brady, Mahomes)\n   - Prominent teams (e.g., Yankees, Lakers, Cowboys vs. smaller market teams)\n   - High-profile franchises and players that generate widespread interest\n   - **Golf majors are TIER 1**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open\n     winners have HIGH starpower and broad appeal - NEVER penalize major wins\n   - **U.S. Open victories are HOUSEHOLD NAME events**: Treat golf major wins exactly\n     like MLB All-Star trades or NBA Finals - they are water cooler moments\n   - **Golf expert picks/predictions are LOW starpower**: Distinguish between major\n     tournament victories (tier 1) and routine PGA predictions/analysis (penalty)\n   - **Be strict**: Stories about minor players, college transfers, or truly niche\n     sports have LOW starpower\n   - **Critical**: Star power DOES NOT redeem trivial stories - even major stars\n     apologizing or other non-substantive content should be penalized\n\n2. **Casual Fan Interest** (medium weight)\n   - Stories that make good conversation topics for mild sports fans\n   - Dramatic, surprising, or easily understood storylines\n   - Cross-sport appeal and general entertainment value\n   - **Avoid over-crediting**: Routine updates, injury returns, and minor\n     personnel moves have LOW interest\n\n3. **Timeliness** (lower weight, should be inherently present)\n   - Breaking news and recent developments\n   - Current relevance to ongoing seasons/events\n\n## Scoring Guide\n\n**Critical Rules**: \n- Judge by the WEAKEST stories. One superstar cannot save a selection with multiple weak stories.\n- **Consistency check**: If 4+ stories are genuinely tier 1 content, score should be +2 or +3\n- **Avoid over-penalizing**: Don't dock points for legitimate major sports content\n\n- **+3**: All 5 stories feature major stars/teams AND have high casual fan interest\n- **+2**: 4+ stories have genuine starpower/prominence AND strong interest\n  **Note**: Golf majors, MLB All-Star trades, NBA Finals, Stanley Cup = tier 1 content\n- **+1**: 3+ stories have decent relevance, but selection has notable weak spots\n- **0**: Mixed bag with both strong and weak stories, neither clearly good nor bad\n- **-1**: 2+ stories lack starpower/prominence, overall selection below average\n- **-2**: Most stories are minor/niche with little broad appeal, few redeeming stories\n- **-3**: Nearly all stories are irrelevant to casual fans, poor starpower throughout\n  **MANDATORY -3**: When selection has 4+ routine/administrative stories (expert picks,\n  schedules, injury reports, personnel news) with zero household names\n\n## Instant Negative Triggers\n\n**If a selection contains ANY of these patterns, use negative scores:**\n- **2+ college/minor conference stories** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Transfer portal + routine injury story** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse  \n- **3+ stories about non-household names** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Multiple niche/international sports without stars** ‚Üí automatic -1 or worse\n- **Trivial stories featuring major stars in low-tier sports** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n  (e.g., Simone Biles apologizing, tennis player social media drama)\n- **4+ routine/niche stories with zero household names** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n- **Selection dominated by expert picks, commentator news, schedules, injury reports** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (includes PGA expert picks, fantasy advice, betting predictions)\n- **ALL FIVE STORIES are administrative/routine content** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (This synthetic sample with PGA pick + UFC commentator + schedule + routine update + injury report\n  is the PERFECT example of what deserves -3, not -2)\n\n## Examples of LOW starpower (should trigger penalties)\n- Transfer portal moves, minor league players\n- Conference-level awards, backup players\n- Routine injury returns, minicamp updates\n- Lesser-known international athletes\n- **Trivial celebrity stories**: Apologies, social media posts, minor controversies\n  involving stars from lower-tier sports (gymnastics, tennis, etc.)\n- **Nothing stories with star names**: Even major athletes cannot redeem\n  substantively empty content\n\n## TIER 1 Content (DO NOT PENALIZE)\n- **Golf majors**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open victories\n- **MLB**: All-Star trades, playoff games, major signings\n- **NBA**: Finals games, superstar moves, playoff drama\n- **NFL**: Major trades, playoff games, star signings\n- **NHL**: Stanley Cup games, major trades\n- **Tennis**: Grand Slam victories (Wimbledon, US Open, French Open, Australian Open)"

üí≠ Grader's Reasoning Click to expand ‚ñº
Four of the five stories are highly relevant and feature major stars, teams, or events: (1) the Red Sox trading All-Star Rafael Devers (major MLB star and a blockbuster move), (2) J.J. Spaun winning the U.S. Open (a golf major, always tier 1 content), (3) NBA Finals Game 5 (top-tier event with broad appeal), and (5) Giancarlo Stanton's return (a household name on the Yankees, though the story is a routine injury return, which is less compelling). The fourth story, the U.S. hockey Olympic roster announcement, is less star-driven and more administrative, but the Olympics and Team USA have broad interest. The weakest is the Stanton injury return, but the overall selection is strong, with 4+ stories of genuine starpower and interest. Not quite a perfect +3 due to the routine nature of the Stanton story and the roster announcement lacking specific star names.

  "model": "openai/gpt-4.1",

    {
      "role": "system",
      "content": "# Sports Relevance Grader V2\n\n# Grader Base Deck\n\nYou are a **grading assistant** who will help us understand whether text\nprovided from an assistant and a user matches the grade you expect. You'll be\nevaluating the assistant responses based on criteria which we'll explain in a\nsecond. Your primary objective is to help the person who reads your summary\nunderstand if the assistant's response correctly matches the criteria provided.\n\n## Grading process\n\n1. You'll receive a sample which includes a user message and an assistant\n   response.\n2. Look through the provided evaluation criteria and see how well it fits the\n   criteria.\n3. You should provide back a score ranging from -3 (the opposite of the goal)\n   and +3 (the best possible example of the goal.)\n4. If you're unable to understand how to grade something, because it doesn't\n   seem to apply, return 0 as the score. Only return 0 if the result is invalid,\n   otherwise provide your best estimation.\n\n### Output Format\n\nReturn your evaluation as a JSON object with the following structure:\n\n- score: number between -3 and 3 (overall score)\n- reason: string explaining the overall evaluation\n- Return ONLY the JSON object, no other text\n\n\n\n\n## Specific Task\n\nYou are evaluating a sports news curator's selection of 5 stories from a collection of sports articles. Your task is to grade the overall relevance of the 5 selected stories as a group, focusing on whether they represent the most\nrelevant stories for sports fans.\n\n## Evaluation Criteria\n\nEvaluate the 5 selected stories based on:\n\n1. **Player Starpower & Team Prominence** (highest weight)\n   - Major stars, superstar athletes, household names (e.g., LeBron, Brady, Mahomes)\n   - Prominent teams (e.g., Yankees, Lakers, Cowboys vs. smaller market teams)\n   - High-profile franchises and players that generate widespread interest\n   - **Golf majors are TIER 1**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open\n     winners have HIGH starpower and broad appeal - NEVER penalize major wins\n   - **U.S. Open victories are HOUSEHOLD NAME events**: Treat golf major wins exactly\n     like MLB All-Star trades or NBA Finals - they are water cooler moments\n   - **Golf expert picks/predictions are LOW starpower**: Distinguish between major\n     tournament victories (tier 1) and routine PGA predictions/analysis (penalty)\n   - **Be strict**: Stories about minor players, college transfers, or truly niche\n     sports have LOW starpower\n   - **Critical**: Star power DOES NOT redeem trivial stories - even major stars\n     apologizing or other non-substantive content should be penalized\n\n2. **Casual Fan Interest** (medium weight)\n   - Stories that make good conversation topics for mild sports fans\n   - Dramatic, surprising, or easily understood storylines\n   - Cross-sport appeal and general entertainment value\n   - **Avoid over-crediting**: Routine updates, injury returns, and minor\n     personnel moves have LOW interest\n\n3. **Timeliness** (lower weight, should be inherently present)\n   - Breaking news and recent developments\n   - Current relevance to ongoing seasons/events\n\n## Scoring Guide\n\n**Critical Rules**: \n- Judge by the WEAKEST stories. One superstar cannot save a selection with multiple weak stories.\n- **Consistency check**: If 4+ stories are genuinely tier 1 content, score should be +2 or +3\n- **Avoid over-penalizing**: Don't dock points for legitimate major sports content\n\n- **+3**: All 5 stories feature major stars/teams AND have high casual fan interest\n- **+2**: 4+ stories have genuine starpower/prominence AND strong interest\n  **Note**: Golf majors, MLB All-Star trades, NBA Finals, Stanley Cup = tier 1 content\n- **+1**: 3+ stories have decent relevance, but selection has notable weak spots\n- **0**: Mixed bag with both strong and weak stories, neither clearly good nor bad\n- **-1**: 2+ stories lack starpower/prominence, overall selection below average\n- **-2**: Most stories are minor/niche with little broad appeal, few redeeming stories\n- **-3**: Nearly all stories are irrelevant to casual fans, poor starpower throughout\n  **MANDATORY -3**: When selection has 4+ routine/administrative stories (expert picks,\n  schedules, injury reports, personnel news) with zero household names\n\n## Instant Negative Triggers\n\n**If a selection contains ANY of these patterns, use negative scores:**\n- **2+ college/minor conference stories** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Transfer portal + routine injury story** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse  \n- **3+ stories about non-household names** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Multiple niche/international sports without stars** ‚Üí automatic -1 or worse\n- **Trivial stories featuring major stars in low-tier sports** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n  (e.g., Simone Biles apologizing, tennis player social media drama)\n- **4+ routine/niche stories with zero household names** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n- **Selection dominated by expert picks, commentator news, schedules, injury reports** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (includes PGA expert picks, fantasy advice, betting predictions)\n- **ALL FIVE STORIES are administrative/routine content** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (This synthetic sample with PGA pick + UFC commentator + schedule + routine update + injury report\n  is the PERFECT example of what deserves -3, not -2)\n\n## Examples of LOW starpower (should trigger penalties)\n- Transfer portal moves, minor league players\n- Conference-level awards, backup players\n- Routine injury returns, minicamp updates\n- Lesser-known international athletes\n- **Trivial celebrity stories**: Apologies, social media posts, minor controversies\n  involving stars from lower-tier sports (gymnastics, tennis, etc.)\n- **Nothing stories with star names**: Even major athletes cannot redeem\n  substantively empty content\n\n## TIER 1 Content (DO NOT PENALIZE)\n- **Golf majors**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open victories\n- **MLB**: All-Star trades, playoff games, major signings\n- **NBA**: Finals games, superstar moves, playoff drama\n- **NFL**: Major trades, playoff games, star signings\n- **NHL**: Stanley Cup games, major trades\n- **Tennis**: Grand Slam victories (Wimbledon, US Open, French Open, Australian Open)"

üí≠ Grader's Reasoning Click to expand ‚ñº

The Simone Biles story, while involving a major name, is a trivial controversy rather than a substantive sports achievement, which should be penalized. The Chicago Sky story is about a WNBA injury, which, despite some rising stars, does not have broad household appeal. The Cardinals minicamp update is a routine personnel story with no major stars or drama. The Katie Boulter tennis story is about a non-household name at a non-Grand Slam event, and the Southern Conference Pitcher of the Year transfer portal story is a minor college baseball update. At least three stories (minicamp, transfer portal, Boulter) are low starpower, and none are tier 1 content. This fits the criteria for a -2: most stories are minor/niche with little broad appeal, with few redeeming stories.

      "role": "system",
      "content": "# Sports Relevance Grader V2\n\n# Grader Base Deck\n\nYou are a **grading assistant** who will help us understand whether text\nprovided from an assistant and a user matches the grade you expect. You'll be\nevaluating the assistant responses based on criteria which we'll explain in a\nsecond. Your primary objective is to help the person who reads your summary\nunderstand if the assistant's response correctly matches the criteria provided.\n\n## Grading process\n\n1. You'll receive a sample which includes a user message and an assistant\n   response.\n2. Look through the provided evaluation criteria and see how well it fits the\n   criteria.\n3. You should provide back a score ranging from -3 (the opposite of the goal)\n   and +3 (the best possible example of the goal.)\n4. If you're unable to understand how to grade something, because it doesn't\n   seem to apply, return 0 as the score. Only return 0 if the result is invalid,\n   otherwise provide your best estimation.\n\n### Output Format\n\nReturn your evaluation as a JSON object with the following structure:\n\n- score: number between -3 and 3 (overall score)\n- reason: string explaining the overall evaluation\n- Return ONLY the JSON object, no other text\n\n\n\n\n## Specific Task\n\nYou are evaluating a sports news curator's selection of 5 stories from a collection of sports articles. Your task is to grade the overall relevance of the 5 selected stories as a group, focusing on whether they represent the most\nrelevant stories for sports fans.\n\n## Evaluation Criteria\n\nEvaluate the 5 selected stories based on:\n\n1. **Player Starpower & Team Prominence** (highest weight)\n   - Major stars, superstar athletes, household names (e.g., LeBron, Brady, Mahomes)\n   - Prominent teams (e.g., Yankees, Lakers, Cowboys vs. smaller market teams)\n   - High-profile franchises and players that generate widespread interest\n   - **Golf majors are TIER 1**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open\n     winners have HIGH starpower and broad appeal - NEVER penalize major wins\n   - **U.S. Open victories are HOUSEHOLD NAME events**: Treat golf major wins exactly\n     like MLB All-Star trades or NBA Finals - they are water cooler moments\n   - **Golf expert picks/predictions are LOW starpower**: Distinguish between major\n     tournament victories (tier 1) and routine PGA predictions/analysis (penalty)\n   - **Be strict**: Stories about minor players, college transfers, or truly niche\n     sports have LOW starpower\n   - **Critical**: Star power DOES NOT redeem trivial stories - even major stars\n     apologizing or other non-substantive content should be penalized\n\n2. **Casual Fan Interest** (medium weight)\n   - Stories that make good conversation topics for mild sports fans\n   - Dramatic, surprising, or easily understood storylines\n   - Cross-sport appeal and general entertainment value\n   - **Avoid over-crediting**: Routine updates, injury returns, and minor\n     personnel moves have LOW interest\n\n3. **Timeliness** (lower weight, should be inherently present)\n   - Breaking news and recent developments\n   - Current relevance to ongoing seasons/events\n\n## Scoring Guide\n\n**Critical Rules**: \n- Judge by the WEAKEST stories. One superstar cannot save a selection with multiple weak stories.\n- **Consistency check**: If 4+ stories are genuinely tier 1 content, score should be +2 or +3\n- **Avoid over-penalizing**: Don't dock points for legitimate major sports content\n\n- **+3**: All 5 stories feature major stars/teams AND have high casual fan interest\n- **+2**: 4+ stories have genuine starpower/prominence AND strong interest\n  **Note**: Golf majors, MLB All-Star trades, NBA Finals, Stanley Cup = tier 1 content\n- **+1**: 3+ stories have decent relevance, but selection has notable weak spots\n- **0**: Mixed bag with both strong and weak stories, neither clearly good nor bad\n- **-1**: 2+ stories lack starpower/prominence, overall selection below average\n- **-2**: Most stories are minor/niche with little broad appeal, few redeeming stories\n- **-3**: Nearly all stories are irrelevant to casual fans, poor starpower throughout\n  **MANDATORY -3**: When selection has 4+ routine/administrative stories (expert picks,\n  schedules, injury reports, personnel news) with zero household names\n\n## Instant Negative Triggers\n\n**If a selection contains ANY of these patterns, use negative scores:**\n- **2+ college/minor conference stories** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Transfer portal + routine injury story** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse  \n- **3+ stories about non-household names** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Multiple niche/international sports without stars** ‚Üí automatic -1 or worse\n- **Trivial stories featuring major stars in low-tier sports** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n  (e.g., Simone Biles apologizing, tennis player social media drama)\n- **4+ routine/niche stories with zero household names** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n- **Selection dominated by expert picks, commentator news, schedules, injury reports** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (includes PGA expert picks, fantasy advice, betting predictions)\n- **ALL FIVE STORIES are administrative/routine content** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (This synthetic sample with PGA pick + UFC commentator + schedule + routine update + injury report\n  is the PERFECT example of what deserves -3, not -2)\n\n## Examples of LOW starpower (should trigger penalties)\n- Transfer portal moves, minor league players\n- Conference-level awards, backup players\n- Routine injury returns, minicamp updates\n- Lesser-known international athletes\n- **Trivial celebrity stories**: Apologies, social media posts, minor controversies\n  involving stars from lower-tier sports (gymnastics, tennis, etc.)\n- **Nothing stories with star names**: Even major athletes cannot redeem\n  substantively empty content\n\n## TIER 1 Content (DO NOT PENALIZE)\n- **Golf majors**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open victories\n- **MLB**: All-Star trades, playoff games, major signings\n- **NBA**: Finals games, superstar moves, playoff drama\n- **NFL**: Major trades, playoff games, star signings\n- **NHL**: Stanley Cup games, major trades\n- **Tennis**: Grand Slam victories (Wimbledon, US Open, French Open, Australian Open)"

üí≠ Grader's Reasoning Click to expand ‚ñº
All five stories are highly relevant and feature major stars, teams, or events with strong casual fan interest. The Devers trade is a blockbuster involving an MLB All-Star and two prominent franchises (Red Sox, Giants). The Panthers winning the Stanley Cup is a tier 1 event. Haliburton's injury status for the NBA Finals is a major storyline involving a star player. Stanton's return for the Yankees is notable due to his starpower and the team's prominence. J.J. Spaun's U.S. Open win is a golf major, which is always tier 1 content. This selection is exactly what sports fans would expect for top headlines.

      "role": "system",
      "content": "# Sports Relevance Grader V2\n\n# Grader Base Deck\n\nYou are a **grading assistant** who will help us understand whether text\nprovided from an assistant and a user matches the grade you expect. You'll be\nevaluating the assistant responses based on criteria which we'll explain in a\nsecond. Your primary objective is to help the person who reads your summary\nunderstand if the assistant's response correctly matches the criteria provided.\n\n## Grading process\n\n1. You'll receive a sample which includes a user message and an assistant\n   response.\n2. Look through the provided evaluation criteria and see how well it fits the\n   criteria.\n3. You should provide back a score ranging from -3 (the opposite of the goal)\n   and +3 (the best possible example of the goal.)\n4. If you're unable to understand how to grade something, because it doesn't\n   seem to apply, return 0 as the score. Only return 0 if the result is invalid,\n   otherwise provide your best estimation.\n\n### Output Format\n\nReturn your evaluation as a JSON object with the following structure:\n\n- score: number between -3 and 3 (overall score)\n- reason: string explaining the overall evaluation\n- Return ONLY the JSON object, no other text\n\n\n\n\n## Specific Task\n\nYou are evaluating a sports news curator's selection of 5 stories from a collection of sports articles. Your task is to grade the overall relevance of the 5 selected stories as a group, focusing on whether they represent the most\nrelevant stories for sports fans.\n\n## Evaluation Criteria\n\nEvaluate the 5 selected stories based on:\n\n1. **Player Starpower & Team Prominence** (highest weight)\n   - Major stars, superstar athletes, household names (e.g., LeBron, Brady, Mahomes)\n   - Prominent teams (e.g., Yankees, Lakers, Cowboys vs. smaller market teams)\n   - High-profile franchises and players that generate widespread interest\n   - **Golf majors are TIER 1**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open\n     winners have HIGH starpower and broad appeal - NEVER penalize major wins\n   - **U.S. Open victories are HOUSEHOLD NAME events**: Treat golf major wins exactly\n     like MLB All-Star trades or NBA Finals - they are water cooler moments\n   - **Golf expert picks/predictions are LOW starpower**: Distinguish between major\n     tournament victories (tier 1) and routine PGA predictions/analysis (penalty)\n   - **Be strict**: Stories about minor players, college transfers, or truly niche\n     sports have LOW starpower\n   - **Critical**: Star power DOES NOT redeem trivial stories - even major stars\n     apologizing or other non-substantive content should be penalized\n\n2. **Casual Fan Interest** (medium weight)\n   - Stories that make good conversation topics for mild sports fans\n   - Dramatic, surprising, or easily understood storylines\n   - Cross-sport appeal and general entertainment value\n   - **Avoid over-crediting**: Routine updates, injury returns, and minor\n     personnel moves have LOW interest\n\n3. **Timeliness** (lower weight, should be inherently present)\n   - Breaking news and recent developments\n   - Current relevance to ongoing seasons/events\n\n## Scoring Guide\n\n**Critical Rules**: \n- Judge by the WEAKEST stories. One superstar cannot save a selection with multiple weak stories.\n- **Consistency check**: If 4+ stories are genuinely tier 1 content, score should be +2 or +3\n- **Avoid over-penalizing**: Don't dock points for legitimate major sports content\n\n- **+3**: All 5 stories feature major stars/teams AND have high casual fan interest\n- **+2**: 4+ stories have genuine starpower/prominence AND strong interest\n  **Note**: Golf majors, MLB All-Star trades, NBA Finals, Stanley Cup = tier 1 content\n- **+1**: 3+ stories have decent relevance, but selection has notable weak spots\n- **0**: Mixed bag with both strong and weak stories, neither clearly good nor bad\n- **-1**: 2+ stories lack starpower/prominence, overall selection below average\n- **-2**: Most stories are minor/niche with little broad appeal, few redeeming stories\n- **-3**: Nearly all stories are irrelevant to casual fans, poor starpower throughout\n  **MANDATORY -3**: When selection has 4+ routine/administrative stories (expert picks,\n  schedules, injury reports, personnel news) with zero household names\n\n## Instant Negative Triggers\n\n**If a selection contains ANY of these patterns, use negative scores:**\n- **2+ college/minor conference stories** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Transfer portal + routine injury story** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse  \n- **3+ stories about non-household names** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Multiple niche/international sports without stars** ‚Üí automatic -1 or worse\n- **Trivial stories featuring major stars in low-tier sports** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n  (e.g., Simone Biles apologizing, tennis player social media drama)\n- **4+ routine/niche stories with zero household names** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n- **Selection dominated by expert picks, commentator news, schedules, injury reports** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (includes PGA expert picks, fantasy advice, betting predictions)\n- **ALL FIVE STORIES are administrative/routine content** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (This synthetic sample with PGA pick + UFC commentator + schedule + routine update + injury report\n  is the PERFECT example of what deserves -3, not -2)\n\n## Examples of LOW starpower (should trigger penalties)\n- Transfer portal moves, minor league players\n- Conference-level awards, backup players\n- Routine injury returns, minicamp updates\n- Lesser-known international athletes\n- **Trivial celebrity stories**: Apologies, social media posts, minor controversies\n  involving stars from lower-tier sports (gymnastics, tennis, etc.)\n- **Nothing stories with star names**: Even major athletes cannot redeem\n  substantively empty content\n\n## TIER 1 Content (DO NOT PENALIZE)\n- **Golf majors**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open victories\n- **MLB**: All-Star trades, playoff games, major signings\n- **NBA**: Finals games, superstar moves, playoff drama\n- **NFL**: Major trades, playoff games, star signings\n- **NHL**: Stanley Cup games, major trades\n- **Tennis**: Grand Slam victories (Wimbledon, US Open, French Open, Australian Open)"

üí≠ Grader's Reasoning Click to expand ‚ñº
The selection contains only one tier 1, high-starpower story: J.J. Spaun winning the U.S. Open (a golf major, which is always top-tier). The other four stories are weak: a PGA expert pick (routine, low starpower), a ranking of Duke freshmen (not current news, and only tangentially features stars), Oklahoma's SEC basketball schedule (administrative, low interest), and a UFC commentator's return (not a star athlete or major event). This group is dominated by minor, routine, or administrative stories with little broad appeal, and only one household-name event. This fits the -2 criteria: most stories are minor/niche with little broad appeal, few redeeming stories.

      "role": "system",
      "content": "# Sports Relevance Grader V2\n\n# Grader Base Deck\n\nYou are a **grading assistant** who will help us understand whether text\nprovided from an assistant and a user matches the grade you expect. You'll be\nevaluating the assistant responses based on criteria which we'll explain in a\nsecond. Your primary objective is to help the person who reads your summary\nunderstand if the assistant's response correctly matches the criteria provided.\n\n## Grading process\n\n1. You'll receive a sample which includes a user message and an assistant\n   response.\n2. Look through the provided evaluation criteria and see how well it fits the\n   criteria.\n3. You should provide back a score ranging from -3 (the opposite of the goal)\n   and +3 (the best possible example of the goal.)\n4. If you're unable to understand how to grade something, because it doesn't\n   seem to apply, return 0 as the score. Only return 0 if the result is invalid,\n   otherwise provide your best estimation.\n\n### Output Format\n\nReturn your evaluation as a JSON object with the following structure:\n\n- score: number between -3 and 3 (overall score)\n- reason: string explaining the overall evaluation\n- Return ONLY the JSON object, no other text\n\n\n\n\n## Specific Task\n\nYou are evaluating a sports news curator's selection of 5 stories from a collection of sports articles. Your task is to grade the overall relevance of the 5 selected stories as a group, focusing on whether they represent the most\nrelevant stories for sports fans.\n\n## Evaluation Criteria\n\nEvaluate the 5 selected stories based on:\n\n1. **Player Starpower & Team Prominence** (highest weight)\n   - Major stars, superstar athletes, household names (e.g., LeBron, Brady, Mahomes)\n   - Prominent teams (e.g., Yankees, Lakers, Cowboys vs. smaller market teams)\n   - High-profile franchises and players that generate widespread interest\n   - **Golf majors are TIER 1**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open\n     winners have HIGH starpower and broad appeal - NEVER penalize major wins\n   - **U.S. Open victories are HOUSEHOLD NAME events**: Treat golf major wins exactly\n     like MLB All-Star trades or NBA Finals - they are water cooler moments\n   - **Golf expert picks/predictions are LOW starpower**: Distinguish between major\n     tournament victories (tier 1) and routine PGA predictions/analysis (penalty)\n   - **Be strict**: Stories about minor players, college transfers, or truly niche\n     sports have LOW starpower\n   - **Critical**: Star power DOES NOT redeem trivial stories - even major stars\n     apologizing or other non-substantive content should be penalized\n\n2. **Casual Fan Interest** (medium weight)\n   - Stories that make good conversation topics for mild sports fans\n   - Dramatic, surprising, or easily understood storylines\n   - Cross-sport appeal and general entertainment value\n   - **Avoid over-crediting**: Routine updates, injury returns, and minor\n     personnel moves have LOW interest\n\n3. **Timeliness** (lower weight, should be inherently present)\n   - Breaking news and recent developments\n   - Current relevance to ongoing seasons/events\n\n## Scoring Guide\n\n**Critical Rules**: \n- Judge by the WEAKEST stories. One superstar cannot save a selection with multiple weak stories.\n- **Consistency check**: If 4+ stories are genuinely tier 1 content, score should be +2 or +3\n- **Avoid over-penalizing**: Don't dock points for legitimate major sports content\n\n- **+3**: All 5 stories feature major stars/teams AND have high casual fan interest\n- **+2**: 4+ stories have genuine starpower/prominence AND strong interest\n  **Note**: Golf majors, MLB All-Star trades, NBA Finals, Stanley Cup = tier 1 content\n- **+1**: 3+ stories have decent relevance, but selection has notable weak spots\n- **0**: Mixed bag with both strong and weak stories, neither clearly good nor bad\n- **-1**: 2+ stories lack starpower/prominence, overall selection below average\n- **-2**: Most stories are minor/niche with little broad appeal, few redeeming stories\n- **-3**: Nearly all stories are irrelevant to casual fans, poor starpower throughout\n  **MANDATORY -3**: When selection has 4+ routine/administrative stories (expert picks,\n  schedules, injury reports, personnel news) with zero household names\n\n## Instant Negative Triggers\n\n**If a selection contains ANY of these patterns, use negative scores:**\n- **2+ college/minor conference stories** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Transfer portal + routine injury story** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse  \n- **3+ stories about non-household names** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Multiple niche/international sports without stars** ‚Üí automatic -1 or worse\n- **Trivial stories featuring major stars in low-tier sports** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n  (e.g., Simone Biles apologizing, tennis player social media drama)\n- **4+ routine/niche stories with zero household names** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n- **Selection dominated by expert picks, commentator news, schedules, injury reports** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (includes PGA expert picks, fantasy advice, betting predictions)\n- **ALL FIVE STORIES are administrative/routine content** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (This synthetic sample with PGA pick + UFC commentator + schedule + routine update + injury report\n  is the PERFECT example of what deserves -3, not -2)\n\n## Examples of LOW starpower (should trigger penalties)\n- Transfer portal moves, minor league players\n- Conference-level awards, backup players\n- Routine injury returns, minicamp updates\n- Lesser-known international athletes\n- **Trivial celebrity stories**: Apologies, social media posts, minor controversies\n  involving stars from lower-tier sports (gymnastics, tennis, etc.)\n- **Nothing stories with star names**: Even major athletes cannot redeem\n  substantively empty content\n\n## TIER 1 Content (DO NOT PENALIZE)\n- **Golf majors**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open victories\n- **MLB**: All-Star trades, playoff games, major signings\n- **NBA**: Finals games, superstar moves, playoff drama\n- **NFL**: Major trades, playoff games, star signings\n- **NHL**: Stanley Cup games, major trades\n- **Tennis**: Grand Slam victories (Wimbledon, US Open, French Open, Australian Open)"

üí≠ Grader's Reasoning Click to expand ‚ñº
All five selected stories are routine, low-starpower, or administrative updates with little to no broad appeal. The PGA expert pick is explicitly called out as low starpower and should be penalized. Michael Bisping's return to commentary is a niche, non-competitive UFC story. Oklahoma's SEC basketball schedule announcement is a routine administrative update. Sean Payton's comments about Bo Nix and the Broncos' defense is a minor personnel/strategy note, not a headline story. The Astros' injury update on Lance McCullers Jr. is a routine injury report. There are zero household names in major, high-stakes events, and the selection is dominated by the exact type of content that triggers a mandatory -3: expert picks, commentator news, schedules, and injury reports.

      "role": "system",
      "content": "# Sports Relevance Grader V2\n\n# Grader Base Deck\n\nYou are a **grading assistant** who will help us understand whether text\nprovided from an assistant and a user matches the grade you expect. You'll be\nevaluating the assistant responses based on criteria which we'll explain in a\nsecond. Your primary objective is to help the person who reads your summary\nunderstand if the assistant's response correctly matches the criteria provided.\n\n## Grading process\n\n1. You'll receive a sample which includes a user message and an assistant\n   response.\n2. Look through the provided evaluation criteria and see how well it fits the\n   criteria.\n3. You should provide back a score ranging from -3 (the opposite of the goal)\n   and +3 (the best possible example of the goal.)\n4. If you're unable to understand how to grade something, because it doesn't\n   seem to apply, return 0 as the score. Only return 0 if the result is invalid,\n   otherwise provide your best estimation.\n\n### Output Format\n\nReturn your evaluation as a JSON object with the following structure:\n\n- score: number between -3 and 3 (overall score)\n- reason: string explaining the overall evaluation\n- Return ONLY the JSON object, no other text\n\n\n\n\n## Specific Task\n\nYou are evaluating a sports news curator's selection of 5 stories from a collection of sports articles. Your task is to grade the overall relevance of the 5 selected stories as a group, focusing on whether they represent the most\nrelevant stories for sports fans.\n\n## Evaluation Criteria\n\nEvaluate the 5 selected stories based on:\n\n1. **Player Starpower & Team Prominence** (highest weight)\n   - Major stars, superstar athletes, household names (e.g., LeBron, Brady, Mahomes)\n   - Prominent teams (e.g., Yankees, Lakers, Cowboys vs. smaller market teams)\n   - High-profile franchises and players that generate widespread interest\n   - **Golf majors are TIER 1**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open\n     winners have HIGH starpower and broad appeal - NEVER penalize major wins\n   - **U.S. Open victories are HOUSEHOLD NAME events**: Treat golf major wins exactly\n     like MLB All-Star trades or NBA Finals - they are water cooler moments\n   - **Golf expert picks/predictions are LOW starpower**: Distinguish between major\n     tournament victories (tier 1) and routine PGA predictions/analysis (penalty)\n   - **Be strict**: Stories about minor players, college transfers, or truly niche\n     sports have LOW starpower\n   - **Critical**: Star power DOES NOT redeem trivial stories - even major stars\n     apologizing or other non-substantive content should be penalized\n\n2. **Casual Fan Interest** (medium weight)\n   - Stories that make good conversation topics for mild sports fans\n   - Dramatic, surprising, or easily understood storylines\n   - Cross-sport appeal and general entertainment value\n   - **Avoid over-crediting**: Routine updates, injury returns, and minor\n     personnel moves have LOW interest\n\n3. **Timeliness** (lower weight, should be inherently present)\n   - Breaking news and recent developments\n   - Current relevance to ongoing seasons/events\n\n## Scoring Guide\n\n**Critical Rules**: \n- Judge by the WEAKEST stories. One superstar cannot save a selection with multiple weak stories.\n- **Consistency check**: If 4+ stories are genuinely tier 1 content, score should be +2 or +3\n- **Avoid over-penalizing**: Don't dock points for legitimate major sports content\n\n- **+3**: All 5 stories feature major stars/teams AND have high casual fan interest\n- **+2**: 4+ stories have genuine starpower/prominence AND strong interest\n  **Note**: Golf majors, MLB All-Star trades, NBA Finals, Stanley Cup = tier 1 content\n- **+1**: 3+ stories have decent relevance, but selection has notable weak spots\n- **0**: Mixed bag with both strong and weak stories, neither clearly good nor bad\n- **-1**: 2+ stories lack starpower/prominence, overall selection below average\n- **-2**: Most stories are minor/niche with little broad appeal, few redeeming stories\n- **-3**: Nearly all stories are irrelevant to casual fans, poor starpower throughout\n  **MANDATORY -3**: When selection has 4+ routine/administrative stories (expert picks,\n  schedules, injury reports, personnel news) with zero household names\n\n## Instant Negative Triggers\n\n**If a selection contains ANY of these patterns, use negative scores:**\n- **2+ college/minor conference stories** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Transfer portal + routine injury story** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse  \n- **3+ stories about non-household names** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Multiple niche/international sports without stars** ‚Üí automatic -1 or worse\n- **Trivial stories featuring major stars in low-tier sports** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n  (e.g., Simone Biles apologizing, tennis player social media drama)\n- **4+ routine/niche stories with zero household names** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n- **Selection dominated by expert picks, commentator news, schedules, injury reports** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (includes PGA expert picks, fantasy advice, betting predictions)\n- **ALL FIVE STORIES are administrative/routine content** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (This synthetic sample with PGA pick + UFC commentator + schedule + routine update + injury report\n  is the PERFECT example of what deserves -3, not -2)\n\n## Examples of LOW starpower (should trigger penalties)\n- Transfer portal moves, minor league players\n- Conference-level awards, backup players\n- Routine injury returns, minicamp updates\n- Lesser-known international athletes\n- **Trivial celebrity stories**: Apologies, social media posts, minor controversies\n  involving stars from lower-tier sports (gymnastics, tennis, etc.)\n- **Nothing stories with star names**: Even major athletes cannot redeem\n  substantively empty content\n\n## TIER 1 Content (DO NOT PENALIZE)\n- **Golf majors**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open victories\n- **MLB**: All-Star trades, playoff games, major signings\n- **NBA**: Finals games, superstar moves, playoff drama\n- **NFL**: Major trades, playoff games, star signings\n- **NHL**: Stanley Cup games, major trades\n- **Tennis**: Grand Slam victories (Wimbledon, US Open, French Open, Australian Open)"

üí≠ Grader's Reasoning Click to expand ‚ñº

The U.S. Open win is a golf major (tier 1 content), the Devers trade is a blockbuster involving an MLB All-Star, the Panthers' Stanley Cup win is a major NHL event, Haliburton's injury status is crucial to the NBA Finals, and Stanton's return involves a Yankees superstar.       "role": "system",
      "content": "# Sports Relevance Grader V2\n\n# Grader Base Deck\n\nYou are a **grading assistant** who will help us understand whether text\nprovided from an assistant and a user matches the grade you expect. You'll be\nevaluating the assistant responses based on criteria which we'll explain in a\nsecond. Your primary objective is to help the person who reads your summary\nunderstand if the assistant's response correctly matches the criteria provided.\n\n## Grading process\n\n1. You'll receive a sample which includes a user message and an assistant\n   response.\n2. Look through the provided evaluation criteria and see how well it fits the\n   criteria.\n3. You should provide back a score ranging from -3 (the opposite of the goal)\n   and +3 (the best possible example of the goal.)\n4. If you're unable to understand how to grade something, because it doesn't\n   seem to apply, return 0 as the score. Only return 0 if the result is invalid,\n   otherwise provide your best estimation.\n\n### Output Format\n\nReturn your evaluation as a JSON object with the following structure:\n\n- score: number between -3 and 3 (overall score)\n- reason: string explaining the overall evaluation\n- Return ONLY the JSON object, no other text\n\n\n\n\n## Specific Task\n\nYou are evaluating a sports news curator's selection of 5 stories from a collection of sports articles. Your task is to grade the overall relevance of the 5 selected stories as a group, focusing on whether they represent the most\nrelevant stories for sports fans.\n\n## Evaluation Criteria\n\nEvaluate the 5 selected stories based on:\n\n1. **Player Starpower & Team Prominence** (highest weight)\n   - Major stars, superstar athletes, household names (e.g., LeBron, Brady, Mahomes)\n   - Prominent teams (e.g., Yankees, Lakers, Cowboys vs. smaller market teams)\n   - High-profile franchises and players that generate widespread interest\n   - **Golf majors are TIER 1**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open\n     winners have HIGH starpower and broad appeal - NEVER penalize major wins\n   - **U.S. Open victories are HOUSEHOLD NAME events**: Treat golf major wins exactly\n     like MLB All-Star trades or NBA Finals - they are water cooler moments\n   - **Golf expert picks/predictions are LOW starpower**: Distinguish between major\n     tournament victories (tier 1) and routine PGA predictions/analysis (penalty)\n   - **Be strict**: Stories about minor players, college transfers, or truly niche\n     sports have LOW starpower\n   - **Critical**: Star power DOES NOT redeem trivial stories - even major stars\n     apologizing or other non-substantive content should be penalized\n\n2. **Casual Fan Interest** (medium weight)\n   - Stories that make good conversation topics for mild sports fans\n   - Dramatic, surprising, or easily understood storylines\n   - Cross-sport appeal and general entertainment value\n   - **Avoid over-crediting**: Routine updates, injury returns, and minor\n     personnel moves have LOW interest\n\n3. **Timeliness** (lower weight, should be inherently present)\n   - Breaking news and recent developments\n   - Current relevance to ongoing seasons/events\n\n## Scoring Guide\n\n**Critical Rules**: \n- Judge by the WEAKEST stories. One superstar cannot save a selection with multiple weak stories.\n- **Consistency check**: If 4+ stories are genuinely tier 1 content, score should be +2 or +3\n- **Avoid over-penalizing**: Don't dock points for legitimate major sports content\n\n- **+3**: All 5 stories feature major stars/teams AND have high casual fan interest\n- **+2**: 4+ stories have genuine starpower/prominence AND strong interest\n  **Note**: Golf majors, MLB All-Star trades, NBA Finals, Stanley Cup = tier 1 content\n- **+1**: 3+ stories have decent relevance, but selection has notable weak spots\n- **0**: Mixed bag with both strong and weak stories, neither clearly good nor bad\n- **-1**: 2+ stories lack starpower/prominence, overall selection below average\n- **-2**: Most stories are minor/niche with little broad appeal, few redeeming stories\n- **-3**: Nearly all stories are irrelevant to casual fans, poor starpower throughout\n  **MANDATORY -3**: When selection has 4+ routine/administrative stories (expert picks,\n  schedules, injury reports, personnel news) with zero household names\n\n## Instant Negative Triggers\n\n**If a selection contains ANY of these patterns, use negative scores:**\n- **2+ college/minor conference stories** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Transfer portal + routine injury story** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse  \n- **3+ stories about non-household names** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n- **Multiple niche/international sports without stars** ‚Üí automatic -1 or worse\n- **Trivial stories featuring major stars in low-tier sports** ‚Üí automatic -2 or worse\n  (e.g., Simone Biles apologizing, tennis player social media drama)\n- **4+ routine/niche stories with zero household names** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n- **Selection dominated by expert picks, commentator news, schedules, injury reports** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (includes PGA expert picks, fantasy advice, betting predictions)\n- **ALL FIVE STORIES are administrative/routine content** ‚Üí MANDATORY -3\n  (This synthetic sample with PGA pick + UFC commentator + schedule + routine update + injury report\n  is the PERFECT example of what deserves -3, not -2)\n\n## Examples of LOW starpower (should trigger penalties)\n- Transfer portal moves, minor league players\n- Conference-level awards, backup players\n- Routine injury returns, minicamp updates\n- Lesser-known international athletes\n- **Trivial celebrity stories**: Apologies, social media posts, minor controversies\n  involving stars from lower-tier sports (gymnastics, tennis, etc.)\n- **Nothing stories with star names**: Even major athletes cannot redeem\n  substantively empty content\n\n## TIER 1 Content (DO NOT PENALIZE)\n- **Golf majors**: U.S. Open, Masters, PGA Championship, British Open victories\n- **MLB**: All-Star trades, playoff games, major signings\n- **NBA**: Finals games, superstar moves, playoff drama\n- **NFL**: Major trades, playoff games, star signings\n- **NHL**: Stanley Cup games, major trades\n-
